resources.string: I found %1$s and added it to your collection.\nDo you want to download their covers right now?\n

Contains information about supported file types for example. You are able to create your own custom platform configuration in [Settings] > [Advanced] > [Custom platform configuration] > [Create].
Retroarch requires a path to the emulator core: For example \'/data/data/com.retroarch/cores/ppsspp_libretro_android.so\'.

Most apps don\'t require an explicit Activity, so you can usually leave it on [Unspecified]. However, some apps need to be targeted with an explicit Activity: Look out for fitting names like \'EmulationActivity\'.

Usually Emulators want to be pointed directly to a \'Game file\'. For some platforms however, there is not just a single file which can be pointed to. In such cases, Emulators often reference to a game through a \'Game ID\' instead (e.g. Vita3K, ScummVM).

The selected platform configuration above does not include an ID file type specification. You can create your own custom platform configuration and add a file type with a specification on how to get the game ID. Go to [Settings] > [Advanced] > [Custom platform configuration] > [Create] to create it.\nYou can still continue to set up this configuration here and save it. You can even try launching a game, but it will most likely fail because I don\'t know where to get game\'s ID from.

The standard intent action to open a document is \'android.intent.action.VIEW\' which is used by most emulation apps. In rare cases a custom action is used: E.g. for Yuzu based emulators, it is \'android.nfc.action.TECH_DISCOVERED\'.
The standard way to pass an ID to another app is through the DATA parameter. Some emulators require the file to be sent through a custom parameter however.
Usually, the ID is passed over as a Text type (\'String\'). If the ID is a number, it is possible that it is explicitly passed a Number type (\"Integer\') though.

The standard intent action to open a file is \'android.intent.action.VIEW\' which is used by most emulation apps. In rare cases a custom action is used: E.g. for Yuzu based emulators, it is \'android.nfc.action.TECH_DISCOVERED\'.
The standard way to pass a file to another app is through the DATA parameter. Some emulators require the file to be sent through a custom parameter however.
Modern apps usually refer to a file through a \'content URI\'. Older apps might use an \'absolute URL\': A hint could be that they use the \'READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE\' permission.
After clicking on \'Launch\' you will see a result here.

‚ùå No game ID found! The configuration specifies to use a game ID to launch the emulator. However, I can not retrieve a game ID from the file type \'%1$s\' defined in the selected platform configuration. Please define in the platform configuration how I can read the ID in the given file type.

‚ùå No game ID found! The configuration specifies to use a game ID to launch the emulator. The type \'%1$s\' specifies to read the game ID from the folder name. However, it looks like the test file is not located inside a folder.

‚ùå No game ID found! The configuration specifies to use a game ID to launch the emulator. The type \'%1$s\' specifies to read the game ID from the file content. However, it looks like the test file does not contain the ID in a readable format: The ID should be the only content of the file.

‚ùå No game ID found! The configuration specifies to use a game ID to launch the emulator. The type \'%1$s\' specifies to read the game ID from the file content. However, I was not able to access the file content.
The custom platform configuration will be deleted and can not be restored.
The custom platform configuration is still being used. Please remove the usages first:\n
This custom platform configuration is already in use, so you can not remove previously added file types.\nYou can either only add new file types or remove the platforms which use this config: %1$s

Papaya processes information about the installed Apps on your device. Additionally, when you explicitly grant Papaya access to certain folders on your device, it will also process metadata of the files located inside this folder (file name, folder name).

Papaya uses the information about the installed Apps on your device solely for displaying the App lists on the Home screen and for guiding you when you set up shortcuts to games inside these Apps (Preselecting installed Apps). This data is not shared with any third party and is only stored locally on your device.

The aforementioned metadata of files in certain folders you grant Papaya explicitly access to, is used to enrich the shortcuts to games in other Apps: The file names or folder names might be sent to api.igdb.com and/or thegamesdb.net in exchange for more details about the game shortcut. Such details include cover images, release dates, genres etc. This additional data is again only used to display them on your Home screen. Please note that this file metadata might only be shared with one or both of these two services mentioned above.

Papaya stores your personal data (Installed Apps, file metadata) on your device. You can erase all of your personal data via Android\'s App settings menu: Long click Papaya\'s App icon, select "App Info", click "storage & cache" and finally "clear storage". Note: Uninstalling the App might not necessarily remove your personal data if a backup option is enabled.

If you have more questions about your personal data and its usage, you can send me an Email: mail@sebschaef.com.

Responsible person: Sebastian Sch√§f
